message: Please discuss about PHP OOP, Coding Standard and Best Practices here...
$_REQUEST should always be escaped and filtered properly...
It should, but just because $_REQUEST is safe it doesn't mean other supers such as get, post and cookie are safe.
Instead sanitise get, post, cookie etc. How this works depends on settings in php.ini
observe get['bob'] and post['bob']: get['bob'] === request['bob'] but post['bob'] !== request['bob'], if you've only sanitised request, post could still be dangerous
i never use $_REQUEST to get values
Too many people do, my co-workers among them ;(
I would like to listen something interesting about this type of var.

I think that usage of this variable can be a bit problematic. I read a lot about this variable and i think, that it's better to avoid to use. Why don't use $_GET or $_POST if you want to get variable which can be placed in request?

The excuses I hear are usually based around the fact that a page will be accessed by get and post, and occasionally data must be remembered from cookies. I'd much rather it got depreciated away and the correct vars be used
Here is the idea: we always escape and sanitize $_GET, $_POST, $_REQUEST and $_COOKIE.
$_REQUEST is helpful in many cases, specially when you want to process same variable from both $_GET and $_POST.
Why would an application have both GET and POST in one page? Not trying to be arrogant, genuinely confused. I've seen this done on some websites.
@manakmichal I don't think I have ever used $_REQUEST either.
I've never had to use $_REQUEST myself and I've never come across a valid reason to use $_REQUEST in any open source project
Yeah, I can't see there being a practical use for it in production
I assume the original idea behind it was some sort of session key related laziness. phpbb springs to mind as an example circa 2005, sometimes passing the key with $_GET, sometimes in the $_COOKIE
I explicitly unset() $_REQUEST to remove the temptation to use it. If you don't know if you're expecting $_GET or $_POST data then you've not designed your code very well.
